items.htmlTitle: gcc - fatal error: Python.h: No such file or directory - Stack Overflow

answer.text: Looks like you haven't properly installed the header files and static libraries for python dev. If your OS is Ubuntu/Debian: sudo apt-get install python-dev
On Ubuntu, I was running Python 3.3 and I had to install sudo apt-get install python3.3-dev
Make sure that the Python dev files come with your OS. You should not hard code the library and include paths. Instead, use pkg-config, which will output the correct options for your specific...
Two things you have to do. Install development package for Python, in case of Debian/Ubuntu/Mint it's done with command: sudo apt-get install python-dev Second thing is that include files are...
I managed to solve this issue and generate the .so file in one command mohanad@mohanad-OptiPlex-760:~/free_Energy$ gcc -shared -o UtilcS.so -fPIC -I/usr/include/python2.7 -lpython2.7 utilsmodule.c
This means that Python.h isn't in your compiler's default include paths. Have you installed it system-wide or locally? What's your OS? You could use the -I<path> flag to specify an additional...

items.title: Python - time.clock() vs. time.time() - accuracy?
items.htmlTitle: Python - time.clock() vs. time.time() - accuracy?

answer.text: As of 3.3, time.clock() is deprecated, and it's suggested to use time.process_time() or time.perf_counter() instead. Previously in 2.7, according to the time module docs: time.clock() On Unix,...
Others have answered re: time.time() vs. time.clock(). However, if you're timing the execution of a block of code for benchmarking/profiling purposes, you should take a look at the timeit module.
The short answer is: most of the time time.clock() will be better. However, if you're timing some hardware (for example some algorithm you put in the GPU), then time.clock() will get rid of...
One thing to keep in mind: Changing the system time affects time.time() but not time.clock(). I needed to control some automatic tests executions. If one step of the test case took more than...
Depends on what you care about. If you mean WALL TIME (as in, the time on the clock on your wall), time.clock() provides NO accuracy because it may manage CPU time.
clock() -> floating point number Return the CPU time or real time since the start of the process or since the first call to clock(). This has as much precision as the system records. time()...
For my own practice. time() has better precision than clock() on Linux. clock() only has precision less than 10 ms. While time() gives prefect precision. My test is on CentOS 6.4， python...
The difference is very platform-specific. clock() is very different on Windows than on Linux, for example. For the sort of examples you describe, you probably want the "timeit" module instead.
To the best of my understanding, time.clock() has as much precision as your system will allow it.
Short answer: use time.clock() for timing in Python. On *nix systems, clock() returns the processor time as a floating point number, expressed in seconds. On Windows, it returns the seconds...
On Unix time.clock() measures the amount of CPU time that has been used by the current process, so it's no good for measuring elapsed time from some point in the past. On Windows it will measure...
Use the time.time() is preferred.

Comparing test result between Ubuntu Linux and Windows 7. on Ubuntu start = time.time(); time.sleep(0.5); (time.time() - start) 0.5005500316619873 on Windows 7 start = time.time(); time.sleep(0.5);...
